Among the entities prohibited to contribute directly or indirectly are governments, corporations, organizations or individuals who are not citizens; that do not reside in the country or have a large share of foreign ownership.
ld: Foreign interests - In order to limit influence over national politics to forces within the country, it is quite common to ban foreign interests from making donations to political parties. Among the entities prohibited to contribute directly or indirectly are governments, corporations, organizations or individuals who are not citizens; that do not reside in the country or have a large share of foreign ownership.

label: Gender equality among candidates
description: Some countries use financial measures in order to encourage and increase gender equality among candidates and within political parties in general. This can include earmarking public funding to women's wings or for gender-related activities, or to reduce the nomination deposit required of women candidates.
ld: Gender equality among candidates - Some countries use financial measures in order to encourage and increase gender equality among candidates and within political parties in general. This can include earmarking public funding to women's wings or for gender-related activities, or to reduce the nomination deposit required of women candidates.

label: Government contracts
description: Private companies that are providing goods, works or services to the government are potentially susceptible to corruption, and conflict of interests when donating to political parties.
ld: Government contracts - Private companies that are providing goods, works or services to the government are potentially susceptible to corruption, and conflict of interests when donating to political parties.

label: Indirect Public Funding [including media]
description: Government provision of resources with a monetary value to political parties or candidates for the election campaign or for regular party financing, such as transport, venues, free or subsidized media access to public or private TV, radio, newspaper or other media.
ld: Indirect Public Funding [including media] - Government provision of resources with a monetary value to political parties or candidates for the election campaign or for regular party financing, such as transport, venues, free or subsidized media access to public or private TV, radio, newspaper or other media.

label: In-kind contributions
description: Non-financial donations provided in the form of goods and services, such as use of venues for events free of charge, using vehicles or non-monetary gifts.
ld: In-kind contributions - Non-financial donations provided in the form of goods and services, such as use of venues for events free of charge, using vehicles or non-monetary gifts.

label: Itemized income
description: Parties are in some countries not only required to disclose their general income as a total amount but also in more detail, listing the amounts received from specific sources allowing more insight into their funding.
ld: Itemized income - Parties are in some countries not only required to disclose their general income as a total amount but also in more detail, listing the amounts received from specific sources allowing more insight into their funding.

label: Itemized spending
description: Parties are in some countries not only required to disclose their general spending but also in more detail, listing the amounts spent on specific posts allowing for more insight into their activities.
ld: Itemized spending - Parties are in some countries not only required to disclose their general spending but also in more detail, listing the amounts spent on specific posts allowing for more insight into their activities.

label: Loophole
description: An ambiguity in the legal framework used to avoid or getting around laws and to exploit the system.
ld: Loophole - An ambiguity in the legal framework used to avoid or getting around laws and to exploit the system.

label: Monitoring
description: The systematic and objective observation and documentation of financial activity, i.e. the supervision of donations to and expenditure of parties, in order to identify irregularities in financial flows.
ld: Monitoring - The systematic and objective observation and documentation of financial activity, i.e. the supervision of donations to and expenditure of parties, in order to identify irregularities in financial flows.

label: Partial government ownership
description: If a business is partially owned by the government, and were to donate to a political party, that would entail a clear conflict of interest and would be a growing ground for potential corruption.
ld: Partial government ownership - If a business is partially owned by the government, and were to donate to a political party, that would entail a clear conflict of interest and would be a growing ground for potential corruption.

label: Political finance
description: The concept encompasses all financial flows to and from political parties and candidates. It includes formal and informal income and expenditure, as well as financial and in-kind contributions. These transactions are not limited to a certain time period.
ld: Political finance - The concept encompasses all financial flows to and from political parties and candidates. It includes formal and informal income and expenditure, as well as financial and in-kind contributions. These transactions are not limited to a certain time period.

label: Political finance oversight
description: Theprocess of ensuring that political parties and candidates conduct themselves in line with the provisions of the legal framework. This may, for example, include receiving reports and investigating breaches, administering the provision of public funding, applying sanctions or hearing appeals.
ld: Political finance oversight - Theprocess of ensuring that political parties and candidates conduct themselves in line with the provisions of the legal framework. This may, for example, include receiving reports and investigating breaches, administering the provision of public funding, applying sanctions or hearing appeals.

label: Political party expenditures
description: The overall spending by political parties on political party activities and election campaigns.
ld: Political party expenditures - The overall spending by political parties on political party activities and election campaigns.

label: Private donations
description: Financial contributions from individuals funding the activities of the political party, the candidate and the electoral campaign.
ld: Private donations - Financial contributions from individuals funding the activities of the political party, the candidate and the electoral campaign.

label: Public funding
description: A system where monetary assistance is provided by the government to qualified political parties or candidates for their campaigns or regular party activities.
ld: Public funding - A system where monetary assistance is provided by the government to qualified political parties or candidates for their campaigns or regular party activities.

label: Public tender/public procurement
description: Government procurement of goods, works and services constitute one of the most corruption sensitive areas of government. A large percentage of state funds are put into public procurement and therefore opens up opportunities for personal enrichment and constitute an area wherein business interests may offer bribes to gain advantages over their competitors.
ld: Public tender/public procurement - Government procurement of goods, works and services constitute one of the most corruption sensitive areas of government. A large percentage of state funds are put into public procurement and therefore opens up opportunities for personal enrichment and constitute an area wherein business interests may offer bribes to gain advantages over their competitors.

label: Regular party funding
description: Non-campaign related finances, including donations and expenditure, of political parties, organizations and associations spent on an annual basis to maintain routine party operations.
ld: Regular party funding - Non-campaign related finances, including donations and expenditure, of political parties, organizations and associations spent on an annual basis to maintain routine party operations.

label: Sanctions
description: Penalties in cases of financial misconduct of a party subject to the regulation. Actions such as irregularities in financial reporting, non-compliance with financial reporting regulation, improper use of public funds may result in either criminal or administrative sanctions including the loss of funds for the party, administrative fines or deregistration.
ld: Sanctions - Penalties in cases of financial misconduct of a party subject to the regulation. Actions such as irregularities in financial reporting, non-compliance with financial reporting regulation, improper use of public funds may result in either criminal or administrative sanctions including the loss of funds for the party, administrative fines or deregistration.

label: Spending limits
description: A maximum amount that a political party or a candidate can spend during the electoral campaign period or during a defined period of time; for example per constituency or per voter. The limit on expenditures sometimes also covers third party expenditures which refer to expenditure incurred on behalf of a political party or candidate by a different entity.
ld: Spending limits - A maximum amount that a political party or a candidate can spend during the electoral campaign period or during a defined period of time; for example per constituency or per voter. The limit on expenditures sometimes also covers third party expenditures which refer to expenditure incurred on behalf of a political party or candidate by a different entity.

label: State resources
description: Resources and powers belonging to the public sector including personnel, financial, material, venues, vehicles, materials and other resources.
ld: State resources - Resources and powers belonging to the public sector including personnel, financial, material, venues, vehicles, materials and other resources.

label: Third-party spending
description: In many elections, not only political parties and candidates spend money trying to get elected - other actors (third parties) may produce and run tv-commercials, put up billboards and in various ways attempt to support a given candidate or political party that aligns with their interests.
ld: Third-party spending - In many elections, not only political parties and candidates spend money trying to get elected - other actors (third parties) may produce and run tv-commercials, put up billboards and in various ways attempt to support a given candidate or political party that aligns with their interests.

label: Vote buying
description: A form of political swindling that is intended to increase the number of votes a particular candidate or political party receives in an election by providing money or other benefits to constituents in exchange for their vote.
ld: Vote buying - A form of political swindling that is intended to increase the number of votes a particular candidate or political party receives in an election by providing money or other benefits to constituents in exchange for their vote.

label: Parliamentary elections
description: Elections to the national legislative body of a country or territory. In case the legislative body has two chambers, only the second (lower) chamber is included. If elections are carried out in two rounds (using the Two-Round System TRS), only the first election round is included.
ld: Parliamentary elections - Elections to the national legislative body of a country or territory. In case the legislative body has two chambers, only the second (lower) chamber is included. If elections are carried out in two rounds (using the Two-Round System TRS), only the first election round is included.

label: Population
description: The total population as described under Voting Age Population.
ld: Population - The total population as described under Voting Age Population.

label: Presidential elections
description: Elections to the national presidency of a country or territory.
ld: Presidential elections - Elections to the national presidency of a country or territory.

label: Registration
description: The number of registered voters. The figure represents the number of names on the voters' register at the time that the registration process closes (cut-off date), as reported by the electoral management body. For more information about Voter Registration please see the ACE Electoral Knowledge Network: Voter Registration.
ld: Registration - The number of registered voters. The figure represents the number of names on the voters' register at the time that the registration process closes (cut-off date), as reported by the electoral management body. For more information about Voter Registration please see the ACE Electoral Knowledge Network: Voter Registration.

label: Total votes
description: The total number of votes cast in the relevant election. Total vote includes valid and invalid votes, as well as blank votes in cases where these are separated from invalid votes.
ld: Total votes - The total number of votes cast in the relevant election. Total vote includes valid and invalid votes, as well as blank votes in cases where these are separated from invalid votes.

label: Valid/invalid votes
description: A vote needs to fulfil a number of criteria to be considered as valid. Examples of such votes include ballots where the voter has marked more choices than he/she is allowed to according to the electoral system. For more information, please see the ACE Electoral Knowledge Network: Criteria to Determine when Votes should Count as Valid.
ld: Valid/invalid votes - A vote needs to fulfil a number of criteria to be considered as valid. Examples of such votes include ballots where the voter has marked more choices than he/she is allowed to according to the electoral system. For more information, please see the ACE Electoral Knowledge Network: Criteria to Determine when Votes should Count as Valid.

label: Voter turnout
description: The total number of votes cast (valid or invalid) divided by the number of names on the voters' register, expressed as a percentage.
ld: Voter turnout - The total number of votes cast (valid or invalid) divided by the number of names on the voters' register, expressed as a percentage.

label: VAP turnout
description: The total number of votes cast (valid or invalid) divided by the Voting Age Population figure, expressed as a percentage.
ld: VAP turnout - The total number of votes cast (valid or invalid) divided by the Voting Age Population figure, expressed as a percentage.

label: Voting age population
description: The voting age population (VAP) includes all citizens above the legal voting age. VAP figures can complement voter registration figures for two reasons. First, registration figures can be inaccurate or unavailable, and sometimes voter registers are not used (as in South Africa in 1994). Second, the voting age population figures can provide a clearer picture of participation as they signal a problem with the voters' register or registration system. The voting age population is based on a country's population over the age of 18. It is not intended to be an exact measure of the number of citizens entitled to vote as it does not take into account legal or systemic barriers to the exercise of the franchise or account for non-eligible members of the population, such as resident non-citizens (the voting eligible population - VEP - would capture these discrepancies but it is very hard to achieve the data required to measure VEP). It is intended as indicative only. For elections held between 1945 and 2001, most estimates of the VAP data are based on the latest census data report in the Demographic Yearbook 1998. This data is produced by the Population Division of the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Estimates for Barbados, the Central African Republic and Niger are based on census data reported in the Demographic Yearbook 1996. Estimates for Albania, Djibouti, Ghana, Guinea, Guyana, Cte d'Ivoire, Samoa, Tanzania, and Togo are based on the medium variant population estimate in World Population Prospects: the 1998 Revision Volume II. The following countries were not included in the statistics produced by the UN Department for Economic and Social Affairs: Anguilla, Fiji, Grenada, Nauru and Palau. For these countries the CIA World Factbook has been used. In all cases the population data selected is either that for the election year or the latest reported before the election year. In the latter case the growth rates presented in table A11 of World Population Prospects: the 1998 Revision Volume 1 were applied to form an estimated population for the election year. For elections held 2002 and onwards the population figures are based on data from the International Database of the U.S. Census Bureau. For all election years, the data was then adjusted to remove population under the age of 18. The result forms our estimated voting age population. Again, the VAP figures are estimates and should be treated as such.
ld: Voting age population - The voting age population (VAP) includes all citizens above the legal voting age. VAP figures can complement voter registration figures for two reasons. First, registration figures can be inaccurate or unavailable, and sometimes voter registers are not used (as in South Africa in 1994). Second, the voting age population figures can provide a clearer picture of participation as they signal a problem with the voters' register or registration system. The voting age population is based on a country's population over the age of 18. It is not intended to be an exact measure of the number of citizens entitled to vote as it does not take into account legal or systemic barriers to the exercise of the franchise or account for non-eligible members of the population, such as resident non-citizens (the voting eligible population - VEP - would capture these discrepancies but it is very hard to achieve the data required to measure VEP). It is intended as indicative only. For elections held between 1945 and 2001, most estimates of the VAP data are based on the latest census data report in the Demographic Yearbook 1998. This data is produced by the Population Division of the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Estimates for Barbados, the Central African Republic and Niger are based on census data reported in the Demographic Yearbook 1996. Estimates for Albania, Djibouti, Ghana, Guinea, Guyana, Cte d'Ivoire, Samoa, Tanzania, and Togo are based on the medium variant population estimate in World Population Prospects: the 1998 Revision Volume II. The following countries were not included in the statistics produced by the UN Department for Economic and Social Affairs: Anguilla, Fiji, Grenada, Nauru and Palau. For these countries the CIA World Factbook has been used. In all cases the population data selected is either that for the election year or the latest reported before the election year. In the latter case the growth rates presented in table A11 of World Population Prospects: the 1998 Revision Volume 1 were applied to form an estimated population for the election year. For elections held 2002 and onwards the population figures are based on data from the International Database of the U.S. Census Bureau. For all election years, the data was then adjusted to remove population under the age of 18. The result forms our estimated voting age population. Again, the VAP figures are estimates and should be treated as such.

label: Postal voting
description: Measures that allow voters to submit their ballot by physical post to the election administration. While postal voting is in principle early voting, it differs in that the vote can be physically submitted remotely by the voters themselves.
ld: Postal voting - Measures that allow voters to submit their ballot by physical post to the election administration. While postal voting is in principle early voting, it differs in that the vote can be physically submitted remotely by the voters themselves.

label: Early voting
description: In-person opportunities for submitting one's vote at a polling station before election day. Other early methods that are not in-person (such as postal or e-voting) or that do not take place in a polling station (such as mobile ballot box voting) are not included in this category.
ld: Early voting - In-person opportunities for submitting one's vote at a polling station before election day. Other early methods that are not in-person (such as postal or e-voting) or that do not take place in a polling station (such as mobile ballot box voting) are not included in this category.

label: Mobile ballot box voting
description: Case when members of the election administration visit a voter either at home or at an institution with a mobile ballot box to facilitate their vote away from their assigned polling station.
ld: Mobile ballot box voting - Case when members of the election administration visit a voter either at home or at an institution with a mobile ballot box to facilitate their vote away from their assigned polling station.

label: Proxy voting
description: Cases in which an authorized individual casts or transmits a ballot on behalf of the voter. While proxy voting is generally restricted to special circumstances, some countries allow it for any reason. In most cases, voters must request to vote by proxy in advance and a procedure must be defined for the voters and their proxy to identify themselves.
ld: Proxy voting - Cases in which an authorized individual casts or transmits a ballot on behalf of the voter. While proxy voting is generally restricted to special circumstances, some countries allow it for any reason. In most cases, voters must request to vote by proxy in advance and a procedure must be defined for the voters and their proxy to identify themselves.

label: Advance voting
description: The opportunity for electors to cast their vote before election day. There are a variety of ways in which this can be done, including postal voting and voting at determined polling sites.
ld: Advance voting - The opportunity for electors to cast their vote before election day. There are a variety of ways in which this can be done, including postal voting and voting at determined polling sites.

label: Asylum seeker
description: A person whose application for asylum in or recognition as a refugee by a country of which he or she is not a citizen is pending, and who claims to fear persecution if returned home. Attendance voting  See Personal voting.
ld: Asylum seeker - A person whose application for asylum in or recognition as a refugee by a country of which he or she is not a citizen is pending, and who claims to fear persecution if returned home. Attendance voting  See Personal voting.

label: Boundary delimitation
description: The process by which a country, local authority area or area of a supranational institution is divided into electoral districts.
ld: Boundary delimitation - The process by which a country, local authority area or area of a supranational institution is divided into electoral districts.

label: Campaign
description: The political activity, including meetings, rallies, speeches, demonstrations, parades, other events, and the use of the media, intended to inform the electorate of the platform of a particular candidate or political party and to gather support.
ld: Campaign - The political activity, including meetings, rallies, speeches, demonstrations, parades, other events, and the use of the media, intended to inform the electorate of the platform of a particular candidate or political party and to gather support.

label: Citizenship
description: The status of being a citizen of a country, which is accompanied by a range of rights and obligations often defined in the constitution or a basic or organic law. Requirements for citizenship vary, and may include being born in a country, having one parent or both parents from that country, or naturalization.
ld: Citizenship - The status of being a citizen of a country, which is accompanied by a range of rights and obligations often defined in the constitution or a basic or organic law. Requirements for citizenship vary, and may include being born in a country, having one parent or both parents from that country, or naturalization.

label: Closed list
description: A form of List proportional representation (PR) in which electors are restricted to voting only for a party or political grouping, and cannot express a preference for any candidate within a party list. See also Open list.
ld: Closed list - A form of List proportional representation (PR) in which electors are restricted to voting only for a party or political grouping, and cannot express a preference for any candidate within a party list. See also Open list.

label: Communal roll
description: A register of electors for which the qualification for registration is a determinable criterion such as religion, ethnicity, language or gender. All electors who meet the criterion may be entered in the communal roll automatically, or each such elector may be able to choose whether or not to be entered. This register is used for the election of representatives of the group defined by the criterion from electoral districts specified for that purpose.
ld: Communal roll - A register of electors for which the qualification for registration is a determinable criterion such as religion, ethnicity, language or gender. All electors who meet the criterion may be entered in the communal roll automatically, or each such elector may be able to choose whether or not to be entered. This register is used for the election of representatives of the group defined by the criterion from electoral districts specified for that purpose.

label: Diaspora
description: Population of a country who have migrated abroad and keep strong identity ties with the homeland. Diplomatic mission  A formal representation of a country in another country recognized under the Vienna Convention, for example an embassy, high commission or consulate.
ld: Diaspora - Population of a country who have migrated abroad and keep strong identity ties with the homeland. Diplomatic mission  A formal representation of a country in another country recognized under the Vienna Convention, for example an embassy, high commission or consulate.

label: E-voting
description: Short form for electronic voting. Any method of voting using electronic means. Examples include casting a vote through the Internet, by personal digital assistant (PDA), telephone or mobile phone, or digital television.
ld: E-voting - Short form for electronic voting. Any method of voting using electronic means. Examples include casting a vote through the Internet, by personal digital assistant (PDA), telephone or mobile phone, or digital television.

label: Elector
description: A person who is both qualified and registered to vote in an election.
ld: Elector - A person who is both qualified and registered to vote in an election.

label: Electoral district
description: One of the geographical areas into which a country, local authority or supranational institution may be divided for electoral purposes. An electoral district may elect one or more representatives to an elected body. See Multi-member district and Single-member district.
ld: Electoral district - One of the geographical areas into which a country, local authority or supranational institution may be divided for electoral purposes. An electoral district may elect one or more representatives to an elected body. See Multi-member district and Single-member district.

label: Electoral law
description: One or more pieces of legislation governing all aspects of the process for electing the political institutions defined in a countrys constitution or institutional framework.
ld: Electoral law - One or more pieces of legislation governing all aspects of the process for electing the political institutions defined in a countrys constitution or institutional framework.

label: Electoral management body (EMB)
description: The organization tasked under the electoral law with responsibility for the conduct of elections. The EMB in most countries consists either of an independent commission appointed for the purpose or of part of a specified government department.
ld: Electoral management body (EMB) - The organization tasked under the electoral law with responsibility for the conduct of elections. The EMB in most countries consists either of an independent commission appointed for the purpose or of part of a specified government department.

label: Electoral register
description: The list of persons registered as qualified to vote.
ld: Electoral register - The list of persons registered as qualified to vote.

label: Electoral regulations
description: Rules subsidiary to legislation made, often by the electoral management body, under powers contained in the electoral law which govern aspects of the organization and administration of an election.
ld: Electoral regulations - Rules subsidiary to legislation made, often by the electoral management body, under powers contained in the electoral law which govern aspects of the organization and administration of an election.

label: Electoral system
description: That part of the electoral law and regulations which determines how parties and candidates are elected to a representative body. Its three most significant components are the electoral formula, the ballot structure and the district magnitude.
ld: Electoral system - That part of the electoral law and regulations which determines how parties and candidates are elected to a representative body. Its three most significant components are the electoral formula, the ballot structure and the district magnitude.

label: Voting from abroad Electorate
description: May have one of two distinct meanings: (a) the total number of electors registered to vote in an electoral district; and (b) a synonym for electoral district used predominantly in some anglophone countries. See Electoral district.
ld: Voting from abroad Electorate - May have one of two distinct meanings: (a) the total number of electors registered to vote in an electoral district; and (b) a synonym for electoral district used predominantly in some anglophone countries. See Electoral district.

label: Entitlement restrictions
description: Provisions in the electoral law and regulations of a country which govern the practical requirements for an elector to cast his or her vote. They may be of two types, legal and administrative.
ld: Entitlement restrictions - Provisions in the electoral law and regulations of a country which govern the practical requirements for an elector to cast his or her vote. They may be of two types, legal and administrative.

label: External districts
description: Electoral districts of which the electorate is made up of external electors, from which representatives are elected to reserved seats.
ld: External districts - Electoral districts of which the electorate is made up of external electors, from which representatives are elected to reserved seats.

label: External elector
description: An elector who is registered as resident outside his or her country of citizenship or otherwise as being not present in his or her country of citizenship.
ld: External elector - An elector who is registered as resident outside his or her country of citizenship or otherwise as being not present in his or her country of citizenship.

label: External voting
description: The inclusion in the electoral law and regulations of a country of provisions and procedures which enable some or all electors of a country who are temporarily or permanently outside the country to exercise their voting rights from outside the territory of the country.
ld: External voting - The inclusion in the electoral law and regulations of a country of provisions and procedures which enable some or all electors of a country who are temporarily or permanently outside the country to exercise their voting rights from outside the territory of the country.

label: Fax voting
description: A mechanism of voting in which an elector receives and returns the voting material by fax.
ld: Fax voting - A mechanism of voting in which an elector receives and returns the voting material by fax.

label: Gerrymandering
description: The deliberate manipulation of electoral district boundaries so as to advantage or disadvantage a particular political interest.
ld: Gerrymandering - The deliberate manipulation of electoral district boundaries so as to advantage or disadvantage a particular political interest.

label: Host country
description: A country that allows external voting to take place on its territory by electors from another country.
ld: Host country - A country that allows external voting to take place on its territory by electors from another country.

label: Immigrant
description: A person who is accepted as a resident by a country other than that of his or her citizenship.
ld: Immigrant - A person who is accepted as a resident by a country other than that of his or her citizenship.

label: Intention to return
description: A specific commitment from a person living outside his or her country of citizenship to return to that country within a specified term, in order to ensure the exercise of defined rights.
ld: Intention to return - A specific commitment from a person living outside his or her country of citizenship to return to that country within a specified term, in order to ensure the exercise of defined rights.

label: Internal voting
description: Voting inside a country which is holding an election.
ld: Internal voting - Voting inside a country which is holding an election.

label: Internally displaced person (IDP)
description: A refugee within the borders of his or her own country.
ld: Internally displaced person (IDP) - A refugee within the borders of his or her own country.

label: List proportional representation (List PR)
description: An electoral system in which each participant party or grouping presents a list of candidates for an electoral district, voters vote for a party, and parties receive seats in proportion to their overall share of the vote. Winning candidates are taken from the lists. List PR systems include Closed list and Open list.
ld: List proportional representation (List PR) - An electoral system in which each participant party or grouping presents a list of candidates for an electoral district, voters vote for a party, and parties receive seats in proportion to their overall share of the vote. Winning candidates are taken from the lists. List PR systems include Closed list and Open list.

label: Migrant worker
description: A person who migrates abroad with the main purpose of obtaining a wage-earning job, often of a nature not requiring qualifications, and often for the purpose of sending remittances to relatives in the country of citizenship. Multi-member district  An electoral district from which more than one representative is elected to a legislature or elected body. See also Single-member district.
ld: Migrant worker - A person who migrates abroad with the main purpose of obtaining a wage-earning job, often of a nature not requiring qualifications, and often for the purpose of sending remittances to relatives in the country of citizenship. Multi-member district  An electoral district from which more than one representative is elected to a legislature or elected body. See also Single-member district.

label: Multiple citizenship
description: The possession by a person of the citizenship, and consequential political rights and obligations, of more than one country.
ld: Multiple citizenship - The possession by a person of the citizenship, and consequential political rights and obligations, of more than one country.

label: Naturalization
description: The acquisition by an immigrant of citizenship of the country in which he or she is now resident.
ld: Naturalization - The acquisition by an immigrant of citizenship of the country in which he or she is now resident.

label: Non-refoulement
description: The principle in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees that No Contracting State shall expel or return (refouler) a refugee in any manner whatsoever to the frontiers of territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion.
ld: Non-refoulement - The principle in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees that No Contracting State shall expel or return (refouler) a refugee in any manner whatsoever to the frontiers of territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion.

label: Officer on duty abroad
description: Any public servant carrying out duties abroad, for example representing his or her government or any regional or international official organization.
ld: Officer on duty abroad - Any public servant carrying out duties abroad, for example representing his or her government or any regional or international official organization.

label: Official external polling site
description: A diplomatic mission or other official site of one country, which is holding an election, within another, the host country, where a polling site is set up.
ld: Official external polling site - A diplomatic mission or other official site of one country, which is holding an election, within another, the host country, where a polling site is set up.

label: Open list
description: A form of List PR in which voters can express a preference both for a party or grouping and for one, or sometimes more, candidates within that party or grouping. See also Closed list.
ld: Open list - A form of List PR in which voters can express a preference both for a party or grouping and for one, or sometimes more, candidates within that party or grouping. See also Closed list.

label: Permanent resident abroad
description: A person who has established his or her permanent home in a country other than that of his/her citizenship in accordance with the laws of that country.
ld: Permanent resident abroad - A person who has established his or her permanent home in a country other than that of his/her citizenship in accordance with the laws of that country.

label: Personal voting
description: A mechanism for voting in which an elector attends at a polling station or polling site in person in order to cast his/her vote.
ld: Personal voting - A mechanism for voting in which an elector attends at a polling station or polling site in person in order to cast his/her vote.

label: Plurality/majority systems
description: Plurality/majority electoral systems are based on the principle that a candidate(s) or party with a plurality of votes (i.e. more than any other) or a majority of votes (i.e. 50 per cent plus onean absolute majority) is/are declared the winner(s). Such a system may use single-member districtsfor example, First Past The Post, Alternative Vote or the Two-Round Systemor multi-member districtsfor example, the Block Vote and Party Block Vote.
ld: Plurality/majority systems - Plurality/majority electoral systems are based on the principle that a candidate(s) or party with a plurality of votes (i.e. more than any other) or a majority of votes (i.e. 50 per cent plus onean absolute majority) is/are declared the winner(s). Such a system may use single-member districtsfor example, First Past The Post, Alternative Vote or the Two-Round Systemor multi-member districtsfor example, the Block Vote and Party Block Vote.

label: Preferential voting systems
description: Electoral systems in which voters rank parties or candidates on the ballot paper in order of their choice.
ld: Preferential voting systems - Electoral systems in which voters rank parties or candidates on the ballot paper in order of their choice.

label: Political party
description: A group of people who hold similar political aims and opinions who have organized, usually to contest elections so that they might form a government.
ld: Political party - A group of people who hold similar political aims and opinions who have organized, usually to contest elections so that they might form a government.

label: Polling site
description: A venue, for example a post office or a diplomatic mission, at which an elector exercising the right to remote voting attends to deposit his or her vote.
ld: Polling site - A venue, for example a post office or a diplomatic mission, at which an elector exercising the right to remote voting attends to deposit his or her vote.

label: Polling station
description: A venue established for the purpose of polling and controlled by staff of the electoral management body.
ld: Polling station - A venue established for the purpose of polling and controlled by staff of the electoral management body.

label: Postal voting
description: A mechanism for voting in which an elector completes his or her ballot paper and returns it by post to an official designated to conduct the election.
ld: Postal voting - A mechanism for voting in which an elector completes his or her ballot paper and returns it by post to an official designated to conduct the election.

label: Proportional representation (PR)
description: An electoral system family based on the principle of the conscious translation of the overall votes of a party or grouping into a corresponding proportion of seats in an elected body. For example, a party which wins 30 per cent of the votes will receive approximately 30 per cent of the seats. All PR systems require the use of multi-member districts. There are two major types of PR system, List PR and the Single Transferable Vote (STV).
ld: Proportional representation (PR) - An electoral system family based on the principle of the conscious translation of the overall votes of a party or grouping into a corresponding proportion of seats in an elected body. For example, a party which wins 30 per cent of the votes will receive approximately 30 per cent of the seats. All PR systems require the use of multi-member districts. There are two major types of PR system, List PR and the Single Transferable Vote (STV).

label: Proxy voting
description: A mechanism for voting in which an elector who is qualified to vote formally appoints another person to vote on his or her behalf.
ld: Proxy voting - A mechanism for voting in which an elector who is qualified to vote formally appoints another person to vote on his or her behalf.

label: Refugee
description: A person who migrates from his or her home and country as a result of political, religious, ethnic, social or cultural conflicts which directly affect him or her.
ld: Refugee - A person who migrates from his or her home and country as a result of political, religious, ethnic, social or cultural conflicts which directly affect him or her.

label: Remote voting
description: A mechanism for voting by which voters are enabled to cast a vote which does not involve their attendance at a polling station on the day or days fixed for voting. Methods of remote voting include postal voting, fax voting, and remote e-voting.
ld: Remote voting - A mechanism for voting by which voters are enabled to cast a vote which does not involve their attendance at a polling station on the day or days fixed for voting. Methods of remote voting include postal voting, fax voting, and remote e-voting.

label: Remote e-voting
description: A mechanism for voting in which an elector may cast his or her vote by means of an electronic device (for example a telephone or the Internet) at any place outside the polling station to which he or she is allocated.
ld: Remote e-voting - A mechanism for voting in which an elector may cast his or her vote by means of an electronic device (for example a telephone or the Internet) at any place outside the polling station to which he or she is allocated.

label: Reserved seats
description: Seats in which a determinable criterion such as religion, ethnicity, language, gender or external registration is a requirement for nomination or election. See External districts.
ld: Reserved seats - Seats in which a determinable criterion such as religion, ethnicity, language, gender or external registration is a requirement for nomination or election. See External districts.

label: Resident
description: A person who lives legally in a country on a long-term basis.
ld: Resident - A person who lives legally in a country on a long-term basis.

label: Returnee
description: An internally displaced person or refugee who has returned home but requires continued assistance for a period of time.
ld: Returnee - An internally displaced person or refugee who has returned home but requires continued assistance for a period of time.

label: Single-member district
description: An electoral district from which only one member is elected to a legislature or elected body. See also Multi-member district.
ld: Single-member district - An electoral district from which only one member is elected to a legislature or elected body. See also Multi-member district.

label: Special external polling station
description: A public or private place located within a host country where the establishment of a polling station is permitted by that host country.
ld: Special external polling station - A public or private place located within a host country where the establishment of a polling station is permitted by that host country.

label: Absence of Corruption
description: Absence of Corruption measures the degree to which public officials (including elected representatives and public servants) abuse their positions through the arbitrary exercise of power for illicit personal or political gain. It also includes lax or selective enforcement of relevant laws intended to prevent significant acts of corruption in the private sector.
ld: Absence of Corruption - Absence of Corruption measures the degree to which public officials (including elected representatives and public servants) abuse their positions through the arbitrary exercise of power for illicit personal or political gain. It also includes lax or selective enforcement of relevant laws intended to prevent significant acts of corruption in the private sector.

label: Access to Justice
description: Access to Justice measures the extent to which individuals and groups can use legal institutions to redress injustices and wrongful acts, including historic wrongs. It also entails a guarantee that all people are equal before courts and tribunals and those accused of a crime have an effective right to a fair trial. That is, that people have equal access to the justice system without discrimination and are also guaranteed due process (free from corruption), including when they are accused and charged with a crime. Access to Justice may also take the form of non-judicial (or quasi-judicial) mechanisms for traditional dispute resolution, transitional justice, and truth and reconciliation processes (Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights n.d.b).
ld: Access to Justice - Access to Justice measures the extent to which individuals and groups can use legal institutions to redress injustices and wrongful acts, including historic wrongs. It also entails a guarantee that all people are equal before courts and tribunals and those accused of a crime have an effective right to a fair trial. That is, that people have equal access to the justice system without discrimination and are also guaranteed due process (free from corruption), including when they are accused and charged with a crime. Access to Justice may also take the form of non-judicial (or quasi-judicial) mechanisms for traditional dispute resolution, transitional justice, and truth and reconciliation processes (Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights n.d.b).

label: Basic Welfare
description: Basic Welfare measures the extent to which a populations basic needs, including access to essential goods and services such as nutrition, healthcare and education, are met.
ld: Basic Welfare - Basic Welfare measures the extent to which a populations basic needs, including access to essential goods and services such as nutrition, healthcare and education, are met.

label: Civic Engagement
description: Civic Engagement primarily encompasses membership in voluntary, non-party, formal associations (Theiss-Morse and Hibbing 2005), but may also include individual participation in collective political activities.
ld: Civic Engagement - Civic Engagement primarily encompasses membership in voluntary, non-party, formal associations (Theiss-Morse and Hibbing 2005), but may also include individual participation in collective political activities.

label: Civil Liberties
description: Civil liberties are those negative rights that are understood to be most closely linked to political activity or personal fulfilment. Some theorists see these rights as being inherent to human personhood (Foster 2008: 3). Civil liberties set boundaries for state conduct, specifying the areas where a citizens freedom of action, conduct, or condition should be legally protected (Katalin 1991) and which can only be limited by the government when their completely free exercise would conflict with other goals of democratic government (Hovius 1986; Gardbaum 2007). Note that civil liberties are generally understood to apply to individuals and not to groups. The list of rights that are included within the concept of civil liberties is not universally agreed upon. However, the most common rights to be included are the freedoms of expression, association, assembly and religion, along with rights to life, property, privacy, bodily integrity and a fair trial. Civil liberties differ from civil rights (at least in contemporary English-language discourse) in that civil rights primarily concern guarantees against discrimination (Schmidt 2016: 1). Some aspects of civil rights are included under Social Group Equality.
ld: Civil Liberties - Civil liberties are those negative rights that are understood to be most closely linked to political activity or personal fulfilment. Some theorists see these rights as being inherent to human personhood (Foster 2008: 3). Civil liberties set boundaries for state conduct, specifying the areas where a citizens freedom of action, conduct, or condition should be legally protected (Katalin 1991) and which can only be limited by the government when their completely free exercise would conflict with other goals of democratic government (Hovius 1986; Gardbaum 2007). Note that civil liberties are generally understood to apply to individuals and not to groups. The list of rights that are included within the concept of civil liberties is not universally agreed upon. However, the most common rights to be included are the freedoms of expression, association, assembly and religion, along with rights to life, property, privacy, bodily integrity and a fair trial. Civil liberties differ from civil rights (at least in contemporary English-language discourse) in that civil rights primarily concern guarantees against discrimination (Schmidt 2016: 1). Some aspects of civil rights are included under Social Group Equality.

label: Civil Society
description: One of the leading scholars of this concept defined it this way: The words civil society name the space of uncoerced human association and also the set of relational networksformed for the sake of family, faith, interest and ideologythat fill this space (Walzer 1995). For the purposes of the GSoD framework, the most important elements of this definition are the space and the networks. We also consider the interactions between these uncoerced associations and the state to be part of this network.
ld: Civil Society - One of the leading scholars of this concept defined it this way: The words civil society name the space of uncoerced human association and also the set of relational networksformed for the sake of family, faith, interest and ideologythat fill this space (Walzer 1995). For the purposes of the GSoD framework, the most important elements of this definition are the space and the networks. We also consider the interactions between these uncoerced associations and the state to be part of this network.

label: Credible Elections
description: Credible Elections is a measure of the extent to which electoral processes are free and fair. Our conception is based on the electoral cycle approach, which emphasizes the importance of the cyclical nature of elections and the ways in which the pre-election, election day and post-election periods are interlinked and impact each other. Based on this approach, our measure of Credible Elections may be impacted by a range of activities and events, including, for example, changes to the electoral law, the process of observer accreditation, candidate registration, polling station irregularities, election authorities independence and post-election audits.
ld: Credible Elections - Credible Elections is a measure of the extent to which electoral processes are free and fair. Our conception is based on the electoral cycle approach, which emphasizes the importance of the cyclical nature of elections and the ways in which the pre-election, election day and post-election periods are interlinked and impact each other. Based on this approach, our measure of Credible Elections may be impacted by a range of activities and events, including, for example, changes to the electoral law, the process of observer accreditation, candidate registration, polling station irregularities, election authorities independence and post-election audits.

label: Economic Equality
description: Economic Equality is a measure of the extent to which individuals and social groups enjoy equal socio-economic rights and ability to exert political influence. Events coded as affecting Economic Equality may overlap with Social Group Equality, but this measure is related to changes in a countrys economy that primarily affect the relative economic position of individuals or social groups.
ld: Economic Equality - Economic Equality is a measure of the extent to which individuals and social groups enjoy equal socio-economic rights and ability to exert political influence. Events coded as affecting Economic Equality may overlap with Social Group Equality, but this measure is related to changes in a countrys economy that primarily affect the relative economic position of individuals or social groups.

label: Effective Parliament
description: Effective Parliament describes the extent to which the legislature fulfils the core democratic functions of a legislature. The core democratic functions of a legislature are: (1) to represent the people, (2) to make laws and (3) to provide oversight and accountability to other branches of the government (Bckenfrde 2011). Some scholars add a fourth function: to provide constituency service through which the members of the legislature assist the people whom they represent in accessing government services (Barkan 2017). This may also be considered to be a particular form of representation (function 1).
ld: Effective Parliament - Effective Parliament describes the extent to which the legislature fulfils the core democratic functions of a legislature. The core democratic functions of a legislature are: (1) to represent the people, (2) to make laws and (3) to provide oversight and accountability to other branches of the government (Bckenfrde 2011). Some scholars add a fourth function: to provide constituency service through which the members of the legislature assist the people whom they represent in accessing government services (Barkan 2017). This may also be considered to be a particular form of representation (function 1).

label: Elected Government
description: Elected Government measures the extent to which key positions within the executive branch of government are selected through competitive multiparty elections. As members of the executive in parliamentary systems are drawn from the legislature, the extent to which the legislature is selected through competitive multiparty elections is also relevant.
ld: Elected Government - Elected Government measures the extent to which key positions within the executive branch of government are selected through competitive multiparty elections. As members of the executive in parliamentary systems are drawn from the legislature, the extent to which the legislature is selected through competitive multiparty elections is also relevant.

label: Electoral Participation
description: Electoral Participation measures the rate at which members of the political community participate in electoral processes.
ld: Electoral Participation - Electoral Participation measures the rate at which members of the political community participate in electoral processes.

label: Free Political Parties
description: Free Political Parties assess the restraints and barriers preventing citizens from organizing themselves into political parties or their equivalents and how free those political parties are to contest elections and compete with similar organizations and parties. It also includes the extent to which elected political parties in a countrys legislature are able to exercise the powers of that office, or whether their ability to participate is limited by unconstitutional or otherwise broadly undemocratic means.
ld: Free Political Parties - Free Political Parties assess the restraints and barriers preventing citizens from organizing themselves into political parties or their equivalents and how free those political parties are to contest elections and compete with similar organizations and parties. It also includes the extent to which elected political parties in a countrys legislature are able to exercise the powers of that office, or whether their ability to participate is limited by unconstitutional or otherwise broadly undemocratic means.

label: Freedom of Assembly and Association
description: Freedom of Association concerns the ability of individuals to formally join together in groups to pursue common interests (Joseph and Castan 2013). Such groups include trade unions, political parties, NGOs, professional or sporting clubs and corporations (Joseph and Castan 2013). Freedom of Assembly concerns the extent to which individuals are able to participate in peaceful gatherings of more than one person, which may be in-person or online, in public or in private. It covers a range of different types of gathering, including meetings, processions, protests, demonstrations, rallies, strikes and sit-ins (United Nations Human Rights Committee 2020; Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights n.d.a).
ld: Freedom of Assembly and Association - Freedom of Association concerns the ability of individuals to formally join together in groups to pursue common interests (Joseph and Castan 2013). Such groups include trade unions, political parties, NGOs, professional or sporting clubs and corporations (Joseph and Castan 2013). Freedom of Assembly concerns the extent to which individuals are able to participate in peaceful gatherings of more than one person, which may be in-person or online, in public or in private. It covers a range of different types of gathering, including meetings, processions, protests, demonstrations, rallies, strikes and sit-ins (United Nations Human Rights Committee 2020; Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights n.d.a).

label: Freedom of Expression
description: Freedom of expression is a measure of the ability of individuals both to express themselves and to hear from others on private and public matters, free from censorship and without fear of retribution or outsized legal or social consequences.
ld: Freedom of Expression - Freedom of expression is a measure of the ability of individuals both to express themselves and to hear from others on private and public matters, free from censorship and without fear of retribution or outsized legal or social consequences.

label: Freedom of Movement
description: Freedom of Movement is a measure of the ability of individuals to reside and move freely within a country or between countries, including the ability to leave and return to a country, for purposes of leisure, employment, emigration and asylum-seeking, without undue impediments or fear of repercussions from governments. The extent to which this right can be infringed upon is subject to national laws, issues of national security, public order and health (United Nations 1966a).
ld: Freedom of Movement - Freedom of Movement is a measure of the ability of individuals to reside and move freely within a country or between countries, including the ability to leave and return to a country, for purposes of leisure, employment, emigration and asylum-seeking, without undue impediments or fear of repercussions from governments. The extent to which this right can be infringed upon is subject to national laws, issues of national security, public order and health (United Nations 1966a).

label: Freedom of Religion
description: Freedom of Religion entails the right to express or practise ones religion or faith, both publicly and privately, and individually or collectively (United Nations 1966a: article 18). It also encompasses the freedom not to practise any religion at all and to be free from the imposition of religion. The United Nations Human Rights Committee has further asserted that freedom of religion includes the right of a person to change or leave their religion, establish a new religious group (United Nations Human Rights Committee 1993), or to be non-religious. The rights of religious minorities should be equally protected (including, for example, in access to education or healthcare) and their members not discriminated against. Freedom of religion may only be subject to restrictions established in law that are necessary for public order, safety or health (United Nations 1966a: article 18).
ld: Freedom of Religion - Freedom of Religion entails the right to express or practise ones religion or faith, both publicly and privately, and individually or collectively (United Nations 1966a: article 18). It also encompasses the freedom not to practise any religion at all and to be free from the imposition of religion. The United Nations Human Rights Committee has further asserted that freedom of religion includes the right of a person to change or leave their religion, establish a new religious group (United Nations Human Rights Committee 1993), or to be non-religious. The rights of religious minorities should be equally protected (including, for example, in access to education or healthcare) and their members not discriminated against. Freedom of religion may only be subject to restrictions established in law that are necessary for public order, safety or health (United Nations 1966a: article 18).

label: Freedom of the Press
description: Freedom of the Press refers to the right of media organizations and individuals to report, publish and distribute information and opinions without governmental censorship, interference or fear of retribution. It rests on three key principles: (1) independence, allowing journalists and media outlets to operate free from undue political or corporate influence; (2) protection, ensuring journalists are safeguarded from physical harm, intimidation and unjust prosecution; and (3) transparency, promoting access to accurate information and enabling the press to scrutinize institutions, thereby fostering accountability and public discourse.
ld: Freedom of the Press - Freedom of the Press refers to the right of media organizations and individuals to report, publish and distribute information and opinions without governmental censorship, interference or fear of retribution. It rests on three key principles: (1) independence, allowing journalists and media outlets to operate free from undue political or corporate influence; (2) protection, ensuring journalists are safeguarded from physical harm, intimidation and unjust prosecution; and (3) transparency, promoting access to accurate information and enabling the press to scrutinize institutions, thereby fostering accountability and public discourse.

label: Gender Equality
description: Gender equality refers to the equal enjoyment of rights, responsibilities and opportunities for people of any gender expression. It requires that the interests, needs and priorities of all genders in their diversity are considered (UN Women 2022). The concept is understood based on diverse perspectives of feminists and gender theorists, who have found the roots of gender inequality in social constructs rather than biological differences, critiqued gender norms which have focused on masculine ideals and challenged gender as a binary conception or an inherent identity (Beauvoir 2011; Irigaray 1977; Butler 1990). Gender equality calls for greater opportunities for women in the workforce and public life, and the need to apply an intersectional lens to analysis, recognizing that factors such as race and class shape (and are shaped by) gender inequality. The concept also addresses the ability of traditionally marginalized genders to make substantial improvements to their lives, going beyond representation and access to resources.
ld: Gender Equality - Gender equality refers to the equal enjoyment of rights, responsibilities and opportunities for people of any gender expression. It requires that the interests, needs and priorities of all genders in their diversity are considered (UN Women 2022). The concept is understood based on diverse perspectives of feminists and gender theorists, who have found the roots of gender inequality in social constructs rather than biological differences, critiqued gender norms which have focused on masculine ideals and challenged gender as a binary conception or an inherent identity (Beauvoir 2011; Irigaray 1977; Butler 1990). Gender equality calls for greater opportunities for women in the workforce and public life, and the need to apply an intersectional lens to analysis, recognizing that factors such as race and class shape (and are shaped by) gender inequality. The concept also addresses the ability of traditionally marginalized genders to make substantial improvements to their lives, going beyond representation and access to resources.

label: Inclusive Suffrage
description: A democratic government must be representative of the people it represents, and it follows that any such government requires ensuring every member of the political community has a vote of equal weight.... However, existing states may choose to extend the franchise to non-citizens living within or without its boundaries, change the voting age, or extend/restrict the franchise to diaspora communities.... A state may also make technical or legal changes that limit or expand the practical ability of enfranchised adults to cast a vote (such as changing the distribution or voting stations or registration procedures), or it could permit a private actor, political party, or any similar such entity to act in such a way that the same effect is observed.
ld: Inclusive Suffrage - A democratic government must be representative of the people it represents, and it follows that any such government requires ensuring every member of the political community has a vote of equal weight.... However, existing states may choose to extend the franchise to non-citizens living within or without its boundaries, change the voting age, or extend/restrict the franchise to diaspora communities.... A state may also make technical or legal changes that limit or expand the practical ability of enfranchised adults to cast a vote (such as changing the distribution or voting stations or registration procedures), or it could permit a private actor, political party, or any similar such entity to act in such a way that the same effect is observed.

label: Judicial Independence
description: Judicial Independence entails the justice system functioning free from influence from both government and non-state actors. Basic requisites for a judicial system that is independent and impartial are laid out in international standards and doctrine, and comprise aspects such as: the duty of government and other institutions to refrain from direct or indirect pressures, interferences or threats to the judicial process; the ability of courts to assert their competence and jurisdiction; the prohibition of special courts; the establishment of objective factors (such as appropriate qualifications and experience) for appointments and promotions; security of tenure, salary and conditions of service; and adequate provisions for disciplinary measures and their independent review (United Nations 1985).
ld: Judicial Independence - Judicial Independence entails the justice system functioning free from influence from both government and non-state actors. Basic requisites for a judicial system that is independent and impartial are laid out in international standards and doctrine, and comprise aspects such as: the duty of government and other institutions to refrain from direct or indirect pressures, interferences or threats to the judicial process; the ability of courts to assert their competence and jurisdiction; the prohibition of special courts; the establishment of objective factors (such as appropriate qualifications and experience) for appointments and promotions; security of tenure, salary and conditions of service; and adequate provisions for disciplinary measures and their independent review (United Nations 1985).

label: Local Democracy
description: Local Democracy is the ability of subnational governments to conduct fair and credible elections, and the extent to which they are selected through them, as well as the degree to which they competently exercise the vested powers and responsibilities inherent in their offices. The GSoD Indices use a strict definition of local, that is municipal, government but the Democracy Tracker is slightly broader and considers higher-level subnational forms as well.
ld: Local Democracy - Local Democracy is the ability of subnational governments to conduct fair and credible elections, and the extent to which they are selected through them, as well as the degree to which they competently exercise the vested powers and responsibilities inherent in their offices. The GSoD Indices use a strict definition of local, that is municipal, government but the Democracy Tracker is slightly broader and considers higher-level subnational forms as well.

label: Personal Integrity and Security
description: Personal Integrity and Security is a measure of the extent to which individuals physical person, personal autonomy, and personal information are free from unwarranted harm or interference from the state or other actors. Personal Integrity and Security can be harmed in many ways, including through actions that kill, maim or injure people; deprive people of their freedom without due process; limit peoples bodily autonomy; or expose information about people without their consent.
ld: Personal Integrity and Security - Personal Integrity and Security is a measure of the extent to which individuals physical person, personal autonomy, and personal information are free from unwarranted harm or interference from the state or other actors. Personal Integrity and Security can be harmed in many ways, including through actions that kill, maim or injure people; deprive people of their freedom without due process; limit peoples bodily autonomy; or expose information about people without their consent.

label: Political Equality
description: [A]ll adult members of the political community should have an equal right to have their voices heard, and be given equal consideration in the formulation of public policy (Beetham 2009: 282). Following this definition, any reduction in an individuals voice and influence due to an ascriptive characteristic or non-political personal choice (such as place of residence or occupation) is detrimental to the overall level of political equality, and thus to the fundamental extent of democracy in the polity. As the concept of Political Equality is so broad, we measure it with reference to three subfactors: Social Group Equality, Economic Equality and Gender Equality.
ld: Political Equality - [A]ll adult members of the political community should have an equal right to have their voices heard, and be given equal consideration in the formulation of public policy (Beetham 2009: 282). Following this definition, any reduction in an individuals voice and influence due to an ascriptive characteristic or non-political personal choice (such as place of residence or occupation) is detrimental to the overall level of political equality, and thus to the fundamental extent of democracy in the polity. As the concept of Political Equality is so broad, we measure it with reference to three subfactors: Social Group Equality, Economic Equality and Gender Equality.

label: Predictable Enforcement
description: Predictable Enforcement refers to the consistent, transparent and impartial application and enforcement of laws by public servants, including bureaucrats, law enforcement agencies and the judiciary. It rests on three key principles: (1) transparency, with laws that are clear, accessible, and publicly communicated, (2) consistency, with laws uniformly applied and interpreted across different cases and individuals, and (3) impartiality, with equal enforcement of laws, regardless of an individual or entitys status or position.
ld: Predictable Enforcement - Predictable Enforcement refers to the consistent, transparent and impartial application and enforcement of laws by public servants, including bureaucrats, law enforcement agencies and the judiciary. It rests on three key principles: (1) transparency, with laws that are clear, accessible, and publicly communicated, (2) consistency, with laws uniformly applied and interpreted across different cases and individuals, and (3) impartiality, with equal enforcement of laws, regardless of an individual or entitys status or position.

label: Social Group Equality
description: Social Group Equality measures the extent to which members of all social groups can enjoy the same degree of civil liberties, political power and opportunities. It also measures whether a particular group (or groups) has a more favourable position in comparison with others in the enjoyment of these rights, and conversely, if a particular group (or groups) faces repression, discrimination or persecution. Regarding the treatment of non-citizens, Social Group Equality relates to the extent to which the rule of law is ensured consistently and without discrimination, and laws and practices are applied in compliance with States international obligations.
ld: Social Group Equality - Social Group Equality measures the extent to which members of all social groups can enjoy the same degree of civil liberties, political power and opportunities. It also measures whether a particular group (or groups) has a more favourable position in comparison with others in the enjoyment of these rights, and conversely, if a particular group (or groups) faces repression, discrimination or persecution. Regarding the treatment of non-citizens, Social Group Equality relates to the extent to which the rule of law is ensured consistently and without discrimination, and laws and practices are applied in compliance with States international obligations.

label: Constitutional adherence
description: Requires public officials or individuals to obey, or abide by, the constitution
ld: Constitutional adherence - Requires public officials or individuals to obey, or abide by, the constitution

label: Territory accession
description: Allows accession or incorporation of new territory outside the country into an existing country
ld: Territory accession - Allows accession or incorporation of new territory outside the country into an existing country

label: Academic freedom
description: Allows scholars to research, teach, and publish their research without interference from the state
parent_category: Rights and Duties/Civil and Political Rights
ld: Academic freedom - Allows scholars to research, teach, and publish their research without interference from the state

label: Higher education
description: Guarantees individuals equal access to higher education
ld: Higher education - Guarantees individuals equal access to higher education

label: Age
description: Relates to a person's age, the length of time the person has lived, or status as a child, juvenile, minor, senior, or elder
ld: Age - Relates to a person's age, the length of time the person has lived, or status as a child, juvenile, minor, senior, or elder

label: Constitution amendment
description: Mechanisms to formally change the text of the constitution, including constitutional amendment, reform, or replacement
ld: Constitution amendment - Mechanisms to formally change the text of the constitution, including constitutional amendment, reform, or replacement

label: Amparo
description: Allows individuals to request judicial review of government actions they believe have violated or infringed their rights
parent_category: Judiciary/Judicial Review; Rights and Duties/Enforcement; Rights and Duties/Legal Procedural Rights
ld: Amparo - Allows individuals to request judicial review of government actions they believe have violated or infringed their rights

label: Anthem
description: Establishes the official anthem or song
parent_category: Principles and Symbols/State Definition and Symbols
ld: Anthem - Establishes the official anthem or song

label: Appeal
description: Allows individuals to appeal a judicial decision in a higher or appellate court if they are not satisfied with the outcome in the court of first instance
ld: Appeal - Allows individuals to appeal a judicial decision in a higher or appellate court if they are not satisfied with the outcome in the court of first instance

label: Bear arms
description: Allows individuals to possess firearms and other weapons
parent_category: Rights and Duties/Civil and Political Rights
ld: Bear arms - Allows individuals to possess firearms and other weapons

label: Art
description: Reference to art or artists
ld: Art - Reference to art or artists

label: Freedom of assembly
description: Allows individuals to gather in groups or protest in public spaces
parent_category: Rights and Duties/Civil and Political Rights
ld: Freedom of assembly - Allows individuals to gather in groups or protest in public spaces

label: Asset disclosure
description: Requires government officials to disclose their income or the value of their assets
ld: Asset disclosure - Requires government officials to disclose their income or the value of their assets

label: Freedom of association
description: Allows individuals to form or join a group or association; allows individuals to not join a group or association
parent_category: Rights and Duties/Civil and Political Rights
